concept.title: Processing XML Data with Custom Delimiters
concept.conbody:
<<<<<<< Updated upstream
text data formatprocessing XML with custom delimitersXML dataprocessing with the text data formatYou can use custom delimiters with the text data format to process XML data. You might use the text data format to process XML data with no root element, which cannot be processed with the XML data format.
When using the text data format in the origin to read XML data, you can use the XML Parser processor to parse the XML data downstream. =======
You can use custom delimiters with the text data format to process XML data. You might use the text data format to process data when you have an invalid XML document with multiple XML objects that cannot be processed properly with the XML data format.
When using the text data format in the origin to read XML data, you can use the XML Parser processor to parse the XML into fields. >>>>>>> Stashed changes
For example, the following XML document is valid and is best processed using the XML data format:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <root> <<<<<<< Updated upstream <msg> <time>8/12/2016 6:01:00</time> <request>GET /index.html 200</request> </msg> <msg> <time>8/12/2016 6:03:43</time> <request>GET /images/sponsored.gif 304</request> </msg> </root>
However, the following XML document does not include an XML prolog or root element, so is ======= <message> <time>8/12/2016 6:01:00</time> <text>GET /index.html 200</text> </message> <message> <time>8/12/2016 6:03:43</time> <text>GET /images/sponsered.gif 304</text> </message> </root>
However, the following XML document does not include a root element, so is >>>>>>> Stashed changes invalid:<msg> <time>8/12/2016 6:01:00</time> <request>GET /index.html 200</request> </msg> <msg> <time>8/12/2016 6:03:43</time> <<<<<<< Updated upstream <request>GET /images/sponsored.gif 304</request> </msg>
You can use the text data format with a custom delimiter to process this data. To do so, use </msg> as the custom delimiter to separate data into records, and make sure to include the delimiter in the record as follows:
The text data format writes record data into a single text field, so you then configure the XML Parser to parse the data in that field as follows:
When Directory processes the document, it creates two records:
text
<msg> <time>8/12/2016 6:01:00</time> <request>GET /index.html 200</request> </msg>
<msg> <time>8/12/2016 6:03:43</time> <request>GET /images/sponsored.gif 304</request> </msg>
The XML Parser converts the data in the XML attributes to list fields within the text map field, as shown. The table displays data types in angle brackets ( < > ):
text <map>
- time <list>:
0 <map>:
- value <string>: 8/12/2016 6:01:00
- request <list>:
0 <map>:
- GET /index.html 200
- time:
0:
- value: 8/12/2016 6:03:43
- request:
0:
- value: GET /images/sponsored.gif 304
======= <request>GET /images/sponsered.gif 304</request> </msg>
You can use the text data format with a custom delimiter to process this data. To process the data correctly, you would use </msg> as the custom delimiter to separate data into records, and include the delimiter in the record as follows:
keep going.
The text data format reads the invalid document as a text file. >>>>>>> Stashed changes
